title: Can I use copyrighted music if I give credit? - Quora

response.answer_text: Whether you may use copyrighted music legally is a question of law, but there’s also a question of ethics. It’s only fair to give due credit to those who create work. Now to the legal quesstions. There are several ways in which you may use copyrighted music for purposes other than personal enjoyment. Get permission. That usually involves paying a fee.Perform the music yourself in a venue that’s paid the public performance licensing fee for you (taverns and concert halls and schools all pay it).Use it for parody or satire.Use small portions in order to illustrate points you are making if you’re engaged in cricitism, commentary, or academic publication.If you record material from a broadcast, you may copy it and share it with others provided you are not making a profit from the transaction..In formal education you may make limited use. Entire works may be used in face-to-face or online instruction but those who can receive it are supposed to be only enrolled students, relevant staff and authorized guests—in online classes that means password-protected. If making a durable copy for students you’re limited to a small portion of the work, for example one photocopy of one chapter of a textbook per student.In worship services. Note that it must be an actual worship service, not a social activity or concert or other event happening in a church, mosque or synagogue.Those are the somewhat ill-defined parameters.

Depends on your usage. 2 cases : Just for fun: If you’re simply making a YouTube video that you don’t wish to monetize, you can use most copyrighted tracks as they’re already registered with YouTube's content id network and the owner of the music will receive all the earnings.Professional: If you’re trying to make original videos for a YouTube channel that you wish to monetize, or a short film/documentary you should strictly stay away from copyrighted music as using such music in a video you’ve put time and efforts in, will have legal consequences sooner or later. It’s better to use royalty free music if you can’t afford or don’t have the budget to hire a musician on sites like upwork. Royalty free music can be paid (one time licenses fees) or free, it depends.No modern art is copyright free. It may have been in the early 18th century, but not anymore. Don’t even consider using other people’s music in your videos if you’re serious about building a career as a YouTuber, Editor or Film producer always hire musicians that will make music specifically for your project only. I repeat again: No modern art is copyright free. It may be distributed for free by the musician to gain exposure but it never is “copyright free”.

Depends on how you’re using it. If you’re performing it in public for pay, almost certainly yes, you can. Generally speaking, the venue where you’re performing is responsible for paying quarterly performance royalty fees to ASCAP and BMI, to be distributed to the various songwriters/copyright holders, not you. If you’re taking someone else’s copyrighted music, adding your own lyrics, and performing or recording it as your song — no. Simply “giving credit” isn’t enough; you would need to get written permission from the copyright holder, and split any royalties or earnings with them.

Only if the music is licensed under a Creative Commons type license which requires attribution. Copying requires permission from the copyright owner. If the copyright owner decided to say that the only payment they want is credit, that is their decision to make, not yours. You can’t use other people’s property without their permission. It depends on where and what you use it for. Are you posting a tutorial with music in the background? Are you posting a cover? Are you explaining something based on someone else’s music? Are you posting on YouTube, Facebook, Instagram, Tumblr, SnapChat, Twitter, or another? Even after answering these questions, you’ll find that using most NOT ALL JUST MOST other people’s music isn’t bad, because most people don’t care since you’re merely spreading their music. Only when you use too much of their’s (say the music video of a song you’re covering) will they be upset.

You can reproduce, publish, distribute, publicly perform, or make derivative works of someone else’s copyrighted music only if you get their permission. Giving them credit is not the same as getting their permission. This is like asking Can I take my neighbor’s car for a joyride if I put o sign on it saying who the car’s owner is?

In order to use copyrighted music, you will have to buy a license to use the song. This is usually through a publishing house, ASCAP, or BMI. Simply giving credit can lead to issues without a license.
No. You have to obtain a license from the owner/publisher, Harry Fox Agency or US Copyright office, depending on type of use. And you have to pay fees.
